705755f-a.text:
(1)
Montague Street, west to Furman Street, showing from left to right, MMontague Terrace and Pierrepont Place, connected by the pedestrians footbridge. At the left, is the Litchfield Mansion, at No. 1 Montague
Terrace, to the right is the mansion of A.A. Low at No. 3.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The same, showing a section of the Litchfield property, and to he
east, the East River and a faint outline of Manhattan.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

704597f-a.text:
Furman Street, west side, north from above Montague Street. A rear view of warehouses on the East River, facing Furman Street. I1 the background, is the Brooklyn Bridge. The Pierrepont Stores at rirht foreground,
were first occupied in 1868.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
704597f-a.folder: Furman Street & Montague Street, Brooklyn, NY

705757f-a.text:
(1)
Montague Street, north side, east from Furman Street. In the center background, is the Residence of Henry E. Pierrepont.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The same, showing the viaduct over Montague Street, at the upper right, and the construction of Montague Street itself.
April 1925.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

704598f-a.text:
Furmen Street, at Montague Street, showing at the left, is a part of the original Jawes S. Nockwell place, later owned by Litehfiel4. The house at the right, in the hollow, used as a saloon is on the S.W. corner of Furnan
and Montague Streets.
1922.
Eugene L. Arwbruster Collection.

(1)
Montague Street, west to Furman Street, showing at the right, the A.A. Low residence, No. 3 Pierrepont Place, and at the left, a section
of No. 2 Montague Terrace, the Litchfield home.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The same, showing a more inclusive view of the A.A. Low residence.
1922.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
